unnormalised: Okay, so finally did that road trip from Bangalore to Mysore I'd been planning forever! Let me tell you, the traffic leaving Bangalore at 7:00 AM on a Saturday was brutal. Took us almost 2 hours to just escape the city limits. Should've preponed our departure time, maybe left around 5:00 AM. Lesson learned, huh?
normalised: Okay, so finally did that road trip from Bangalore to Mysore I had been planning forever! Let me tell you, the traffic leaving Bangalore at seven AM on a Saturday was brutal. Took us almost two hours to just escape the city limits. Should have preponed our departure time, maybe left around five AM. Lesson learned, huh?

unnormalised: Anyway, once we were on the highway, it was smooth sailing. The NH275 is mostly well-maintained, though there were a few bumpy patches near Ramanagara. We stopped for breakfast at a Kamat Lokaruchi – always a safe bet for dosas and filter coffee, right? Spent maybe 45 minutes there refuelling ourselves.
normalised: Anyway, once we were on the highway, it was smooth sailing. The N-H two seventy five is mostly well maintained, though there were a few bumpy patches near Ramanagara. We stopped for breakfast at a Kamat Lokaruchi – always a safe bet for dosas and filter coffee, right? Spent maybe forty five minutes there refuelling ourselves.

unnormalised: The scenery along the way is actually quite nice. Lots of green fields, coconut trees… typical Karnataka countryside. We even spotted a couple of farmers herding sheep. Classic India! We made a quick pit stop at Channapatna, you know, the town famous for wooden toys. Picked up a few souvenirs for the kids back home. Cost me around Rs. 500 for a couple of toys.
normalised: The scenery along the way is actually quite nice. Lots of green fields, coconut trees… typical Karnataka countryside. We even spotted a couple of farmers herding sheep. Classic India! We made a quick pit stop at Channapatna, you know, the town famous for wooden toys. Picked up a few souvenirs for the kids back home. Cost me around rupee five hundred for a couple of toys.

unnormalised: One thing I wasn't prepared for was the sheer number of toll booths. Felt like we were stopping every 30 km to pay toll tax. Each one cost between Rs. 50 to Rs. 100, which adds up over the entire journey. Guess that's the price you pay for decent roads, eh?
normalised: One thing I was not prepared for was the sheer number of toll booths. Felt like we were stopping every thirty kilometer to pay toll tax. Each one cost between rupee fifty to rupee one hundred, which adds up over the entire journey. Guess that is the price you pay for decent roads, eh?

unnormalised: We reached Mysore around 1:00 PM, checked into our hotel near the Mysore Palace, and then immediately headed out for lunch. Found this amazing little place serving Mysore Masala Dosa - it was divine! Cost Rs. 80. The Mysore Palace, btw, is absolutely stunning. Especially when it’s lit up at night. Managed to click some amazing pics.
normalised: We reached Mysore around one PM, checked into our hotel near the Mysore Palace, and then immediately headed out for lunch. Found this amazing little place serving Mysore Masala Dosa - it was divine! Cost rupee eighty. The Mysore Palace, by the way, is absolutely stunning. Especially when it is lit up at night. Managed to click some amazing pics.

unnormalised: Next day we hired an auto-rickshaw to explore the local markets. The auto driver, Raju, was a total gem. He knew all the best spots for silk sarees and sandalwood products. Bargained a bit and managed to get a decent deal on a saree for my wife. Paid around ₹2500 for it.
normalised: Next day we hired an auto rickshaw to explore the local markets. The auto driver, Raju, was a total gem. He knew all the best spots for silk sarees and sandalwood products. Bargained a bit and managed to get a decent deal on a saree for my wife. Paid around rupee two thousand five hundred for it.

unnormalised: We also visited Chamundi Hills, which offers a panoramic view of Mysore city. The climb up was a bit tiring, but totally worth it. Spotted quite a few monkeys on the way, so had to be careful with our belongings.
normalised: We also visited Chamundi Hills, which offers a panoramic view of Mysore city. The climb up was a bit tiring, but totally worth it. Spotted quite a few monkeys on the way, so had to be careful with our belongings.

unnormalised: The drive back to Bangalore on Sunday evening was even more chaotic than the journey to Mysore. Traffic was bumper-to-bumper for almost the entire stretch. Took us nearly 6 hours to reach home. We finally reached around 11:00 PM, completely exhausted but happy.
normalised: The drive back to Bangalore on Sunday evening was even more chaotic than the journey to Mysore. Traffic was bumper to bumper for almost the entire stretch. Took us nearly six hours to reach home. We finally reached around eleven PM, completely exhausted but happy.

unnormalised: Overall, the Bangalore to Mysore road trip was a great experience. A little tiring, maybe, but definitely worth it. Just remember to factor in extra time for traffic, especially if you're travelling on a weekend.
normalised: Overall, the Bangalore to Mysore road trip was a great experience. A little tiring, maybe, but definitely worth it. Just remember to factor in extra time for traffic, especially if you are travelling on a weekend.

unnormalised: Pro-tip: Download offline maps, mobile network can be spotty in certain areas. And carry snacks and water, especially if you're travelling with kids. Would rate the experience a solid 7/10. Will I do it again? Maybe… but next time, I’m taking the train! Costs only Rs. 350 for a sleeper class ticket.
